Grid

  • Basics
  • Nesting

  • Responsive Classes

Basics

How to use

The grid is built around three key elements: containers, rows, and columns. Containers create base padding for the page; rows create a max-width and contain the columns; and columns create the final structure. Everything on your page that you don't give a specific structural style to should be within a container, row and column.

warning Columns don't have a fixed width: they can vary based on the resolution of the screen, or the size of the window (try scaling down this window to see it).

Code

<div class="container">
  <div class="grid-row">
    <div class="grid-8">
      Eight columns
    </div>
    <div class="grid-4">
      Four columns					
    </div>
  </div>
</div>

Sample

Nesting

How to use

In the Grid you can nest columns down as far as you'd like. Just embed rows inside columns and go from there. Each embedded row can contain up to 12 columns.

Code

<div class="grid-row">
  <div class="grid-8">
    <div class="grid-row">
      <div class="grid-6">
        Six columns (nested)
      </div>
      <div class="grid-6">
        Six columns (nested)
      </div>
    </div>
  </div>
  <div class="grid-4">
  </div>
</div>

Sample

Offsets

How to use

Offsets allow you to create additional space between columns in a row. The offsets run from grid-offset-1 all the way up to grid-offset-11. Like the rest of the grid they're nestable.

Code

<div class="grid-row">
  <div class="grid-4 grid-offset-4">
    Four columns offset by four			
  </div>
  <div class="grid-4">
    Four columns					
  </div>
</div>

Sample

Centered Columns

How to use

Centered columns are placed in the middle of the row. This does not center their content, but centers the grid element itself. This is a convenient way to make sure a block is centered, even if you change the number of columns it contains. Note: for this to work, there cannot be any other column blocks in the row.

Code

<div class="grid-row">
  <div class="grid-4 grid-centered">
    Four columns centered			
  </div>
</div>

Sample

Source Order

How to use

Sometimes within the grid you want the order of your markup to not necessarily be the same as the order items are flowed into the grid. Using these source ordering classes you can shift columns around on desktops and tablets. On phones the grid will still be linearized into the order of the markup.

notice The syntax supports push and pull for two to ten columns, and is added directly to the columns themselves.

Code

<div class="grid-row">
  <div class="grid-2 grid-push-10">
    Two columns		
  </div>
  <div class="grid-10 grid-pull-2">
    Ten columns
  </div>
</div>

<div class="grid-row">
  <div class="grid-7 grid-push-5">
    Seven columns				
  </div>
  <div class="grid-5 grid-pull-7">
    Five columns (last)
  </div>
</div>

Sample
